awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ecological Restoration and Indigenous Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

The doctoral dissertation project examines North American Indigenous relationships to ecology and how Indigenous knowledge systems have developed and changed over time, with particular attention to socioeconomic difference, health, and environmental change. Globally, ecosystem changes due to environmental disturbance, natural events, climate change, or a combination thereof leads to species being unable to adapt. This directly impacts societies where relationships to the natural world are an integral dimension of everyday life. This project, which supports the training of an Indigenous graduate student in anthropology in empirical, social scientific data collection and analysis, considers how an Indigenous community addresses the political and environmental forces that impact everyday life and expressions of identity and community health as they relate to Lake Sturgeon (Nmé) restoration. 

This doctoral research investigates how the enactment of the Nmé Stewardship Plan correlates with Odawa expressions of identity, understandings of health, and legal relationships with the environment. How is the Little River Odawa community navigating contemporary environmental and social impacts from the historical depletion and current restoration of Lake Sturgeon (Nmé)? What role do Indigenous and Western science play in affecting these views and practices? What does this mean for Odawa treaty rights in the face of climate change? To answer these questions the researcher interviews community members and tribal natural resource managers and carries out participant observation in daily community activities related to fishing. Archival research at university and government archives adds further depth to the study. The resulting research products contribute to an understanding of Indigenous science and how it encompasses humans' accountability towards the environment and identifies opportunities for strengthened environmental planning at local, regional, and national scales. This has implications for both Indigenous peoples and for the study of species restoration across the ecological and social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Natasha Myhal has completed research for her dissertation “Ecological Restoration and Indigenous Science” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant in Cultural Anthropology. During her funding period, she spent 11 months at the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians Tribal Natural Resources Department (NRD) working with tribal natural resource department professionals and community members with their ongoing Lake Sturgeon restoration program in an effort to understand how this particular species of fish, as well as the entire watershed, is undergoing transformations due to climate change. As an Indigenous anthropologist, Myhal was interested in understanding how lake sturgeon focused tribal natural resource managers are restoring the relationship between this non-human, the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, and the broader community. She was specifically focused on learning the techniques of caring for sturgeon that the NRD employees use and the role of tribal members oral narratives to understand climate change.

 

As an engaged participant observer, Myhal accomplished the goal of her research and worked closely with the sturgeon restoration program and conducted 20 semi-structured interviews with tribal members. In addition to her work with the NRD, Myhal volunteered within the community to build community relations outside normative tribal government structures. She worked with the Elders Meal Program coordinator as a volunteer, to learn more about the broader challenges and inspirations from the community members themselves. From the interviews, she will provide the data to the tribal natural resource department as they create a climate change management plan based off Myhal’s interviews.

 

Myhal also visited six archives during her grant period to view correspondence, reports and research materials related to the Anishinaabe activites 1830-present that concern sturgeon, and the broader US-Anishinaabe relationships including the signing of the 1836 Treaty of Washington. The basis of her visits to these archives was to understand the historical conditions that led to lake sturgeon’s decline, to help determine the range and variability of ecological processes and human’s effects on them. Myhal also sought out historical records, from Indian agencies in Michigan, that detailed tribal affairs and daily life during the nineteenth century. Both together, examines how human-environmental relationships provide a deep time perspective on the evolution of ecosystems, and the place of the Anishinaabe in those ecosystems. Yet, Myhal found a noticeably absent record of sturgeon in Michigan, and most of what she found pertained to the Menominee Tribe in Wisconsin and their relationship with sturgeon. If Michigan’s historical records mentioned sturgeon it was only briefly mentioned.

 

Myhal’s research at the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians forms the basis of her dissertation. To be completed in 2023, the dissertation is an important contribution to Environmental Studies and Sciences because it asserts how Indigenous knowledge are center to addressing climate and environmental change and adaptation.
